study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of 3 g cinnamon on gastric emptying, postprandial lipemic and glycemic responses, oxidative stress, arterial stiffness, and appetite following a high-fat meal.
results_summary: Cinnamon had no significant effect on gastric emptying, postprandial triacylglycerol or glucose levels, oxidative stress, arterial function, or appetite. No evidence supported its use for metabolic disease prevention or treatment.
population_specificity: Nine healthy, young subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the scientific literature on Cinnamomum aromaticum and Cinnamomum zeylanicum, focusing on their potential health benefits, particularly hypoglycemic activity, and other therapeutic properties.
results_summary: The study found that cinnamon exhibits multiple health benefits, including hypoglycemic, anti-microbial, anti-fungal, antiviral, antioxidant, anti-tumour, blood pressure-lowering, and cholesterol-lowering effects in animal models, but clinical trials showed conflicting results regarding anti-diabetic activity.
population_specificity: Animal models and limited human clinical trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the analgesic effects of a herbal ointment containing cinnamon, ginger, mastic, and sesame oil with Salicylate ointment in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The herbal ointment showed comparable efficacy to Salicylate ointment in reducing pain, morning stiffness, and limited motion, with statistically significant improvements observed over six weeks. No significant differences were found between the two treatments.
population_specificity: Patients with diagnosed knee osteoarthritis (mean age 52.2 years, mean disease duration 30.45 months).
effective_dosage: Applied twice daily (specific amount not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of maoto (containing Cinnamon Bark) with neuraminidase inhibitors (oseltamivir and zanamivir) for treating influenza symptoms in adults.
results_summary: Maoto, which includes Cinnamon Bark, showed a median fever duration (29h) comparable to zanamivir (27h) and significantly shorter than oseltamivir (46h). No significant differences were found in symptom scores, viral persistence, or cytokine levels among the groups.
population_specificity: Adult patients with influenza symptoms (fever onset within 48h, positive quick diagnostic test).
effective_dosage: Not specified (maoto granules as a commercial medical dosage form).
study_duration: Symptoms and outcomes were monitored over 5 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cinnamon raisin flavoring could improve the acceptability of flaxseed-fortified bagels for use in clinical trials or daily diets.
results_summary: The study found that cinnamon raisin bagels had significantly higher flavor acceptance compared to plain and sunflower sesame bagels, masking the flaxseed aroma and flavor while maintaining acceptability. Older consumers rated the cinnamon raisin bagels more favorably, suggesting better compliance in this age group.
population_specificity: Trained sensory panel (9 members) and consumer test participants (89 individuals), with noted differences in preference between older and younger consumers.
effective_dosage: Not specified (flaxseed content was 23% by weight of raw ingredients, but cinnamon dosage was not detailed).
study_duration: Not specified (sensory and consumer tests were conducted, but intervention duration was not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the antifungal properties of traditional Chinese medicinal herbs, including cinnamon, against candidiasis in HIV/AIDS patients.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that cinnamon, among other herbs, exhibits antifungal activity in vitro against Candida, but clinical safety and efficacy remain unverified.
population_specificity: HIV/AIDS patients with candidiasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether cinnamon extract could attenuate insulin resistance and reduce cardiovascular risk factors associated with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The study suggests that cinnamon extract may help reduce insulin resistance and cardiovascular risk factors in metabolic syndrome, but more clinical trials are needed to determine optimal dosage and duration.
population_specificity: Individuals with metabolic syndrome (a cluster of cardiovascular disease risk factors linked to insulin resistance).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cinnamon intake lowers fasting blood glucose (FBG) in people with type 2 diabetes and/or prediabetes.
results_summary: Cinnamon intake, either as whole cinnamon or extract, significantly lowered FBG (-0.49±0.2 mmol/L; P=.025). Cinnamon extract alone also showed a significant reduction (-0.48 mmol/L±0.17; P=.008).
population_specificity: People with type 2 diabetes and/or prediabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of cassia cinnamon in the treatment or prevention of type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study identified cassia cinnamon as one of several nutritional supplements potentially beneficial for type 2 diabetes treatment or prevention, though specific efficacy details were not provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with or at risk of type 2 diabetes (general population focus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cinnamon supplementation improves metabolic measures, particularly blood pressure and glycemic control, in adults with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found a modest but statistically significant difference in systolic blood pressure (SBP) change between the cinnamon and placebo groups, though this effect was likely due to regression to the mean rather than treatment. No significant improvements in other metabolic measures were reported.
population_specificity: Adults aged 30+ with type 2 diabetes (mean age 63.05±10.85 years; 40.7% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of a DA-IBS formula containing cinnamon quills on bowel habits and abdominal symptoms in patients with diarrhea-predominant or alternating bowel habit IBS.
results_summary: The DA-IBS formula with cinnamon significantly improved abdominal pain, bloating, flatulence, and global IBS symptoms but did not effectively improve bowel habit frequency.
population_specificity: 31 patients with IBS (21 with diarrhea-predominant or alternating bowel habit, 10 with constipation-predominant).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential health benefits of cinnamon, particularly its anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, antioxidant, and hypoglycemic properties, with a focus on its use in type 2 diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: In vitro and animal studies suggest cinnamon has anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, antioxidant, and hypoglycemic effects, but clinical evidence is limited. The most promising application is as an adjunct for type 2 diabetes, though more research is needed.
population_specificity: In vitro, animal models, and limited human clinical studies (not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine cinnamon's effects on HbA1c, blood pressure, and lipid profiles in type 2 diabetes patients.
results_summary: Cinnamon significantly reduced HbA1c, systolic and diastolic blood pressure, and showed modest improvements in fasting plasma glucose, waist circumference, and BMI, though lipid profiles remained unchanged.
population_specificity: 58 type 2 diabetes patients (25 males, 33 females, aged 54.9 ± 9.8) with HbA1c >7% on hypoglycemic agents.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of cinnamon supplementation on obesity indices by conducting an umbrella meta-analysis of existing meta-analyses.
results_summary: The pooled effects of 7 meta-analyses showed that cinnamon supplementation significantly reduced body weight and body mass index, with statistically significant effect sizes.
population_specificity: Not specified (meta-analysis of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety of coumarin exposure from cassia cinnamon consumption, particularly during the Christmas season in Germany, and compare it to the tolerable daily intake (TDI).
results_summary: The study found that heavy consumers of cassia cinnamon may reach a daily coumarin intake corresponding to the TDI of 0.1 mg/kg body weight, which was derived from both animal and human data. A subgroup of the human population was identified as more susceptible to coumarin's hepatotoxic effects, though the cause remains unknown.
population_specificity: General population in Germany, with a focus on heavy consumers of cassia cinnamon during the Christmas season.
effective_dosage: Not specified (exposure estimated based on dietary habits)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of cinnamon supplementation on obesity measures, including body weight, BMI, waist circumference, and fat mass in adults.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that cinnamon supplementation significantly reduced body weight, BMI, and waist circumference, suggesting it could be effective as a weight-reducing supplement in obesity management.
population_specificity: Adults (786 subjects across 12 trials)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and meta-analyze randomized controlled trials (RCTs) assessing the effect of cinnamon on blood pressure (BP).
results_summary: The study found that cinnamon supplementation had a significant favorable effect on diastolic blood pressure (DBP) but not on systolic blood pressure (SBP) overall, though long-duration (≥8 weeks) and high-dose (>1500 mg/day) cinnamon supplementation did show significant effects on SBP.
population_specificity: Adults (582 participants across 8 trials).
effective_dosage: High dose (>1500 mg/day) was noted as effective.
study_duration: Long-duration (≥8 weeks) was noted as effective.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Cassia cinnamon improves insulin resistance, insulin sensitivity, and blood glucose response to an oral glucose tolerance test in young, sedentary, obese women.
results_summary: Cassia cinnamon significantly reduced peak blood glucose at 30 minutes post-OGTT but did not significantly affect insulin resistance, insulin sensitivity, or overall glucose and insulin area-under-the-curve responses compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Young, sedentary, obese women
effective_dosage: 5 g encapsulated Cassia cinnamon bark (single dose)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of cinnamon supplementation on migraine attacks and inflammatory status by measuring serum levels of IL-6, CGRP, and NO, as well as migraine frequency, severity, and duration.
results_summary: Cinnamon supplementation significantly reduced serum IL-6 and NO levels and decreased migraine frequency, severity, and duration compared to placebo. However, CGRP levels remained unchanged in both groups.
population_specificity: Fifty patients with migraine.
effective_dosage: Three capsules/day, each containing 600 mg of cinnamon.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of topical Ciplukan as an anti-inflammatory agent by targeting the expression of IL-17 and IFN-γ in psoriasis vulgaris.
results_summary: Ciplukan significantly reduced IL-17 and IFN-γ expression compared to the psoriasis control group, with no significant difference compared to standard mometasone furoate therapy. The 1:2 ratio (Ciplukan:vaseline) showed the most pronounced effects.
population_specificity: Mice with imiquimod-induced psoriasis.
effective_dosage: 1:2 and 1:4 ratios of Ciplukan to vaseline (exact amounts not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of cinnamon supplementation on serum C-reactive protein (CRP) levels through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Pooled analysis showed significant reductions in serum CRP levels, particularly in trials with baseline CRP >3 mg/dL and durations >12 weeks. Both lower (<1500 mg/day) and higher (≥1500 mg/day) doses were effective, with reduced heterogeneity in lower-dose trials.
population_specificity: 285 participants from six randomized controlled trials (specific population details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Ciplukan extract as adjuvant therapy improves skin fibrosis in scleroderma patients based on MRSS, inflammatory biomarkers, and serum fibrosis markers.
results_summary: The study found significant improvement in skin fibrosis in the treatment group, with a highly significant decrease in MRSS (35.9% vs. 6.3%) and a relative decrease in P1NP levels (17.8% vs. 0.7%). No significant changes were observed in ESR, BAFF, or sCD40L levels.
population_specificity: Scleroderma patients with stable disease (average age 41, 90% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic effects of Cissus quadrangularis extract (CQR-300) on type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) in a leptin receptor-mutated db/db mouse model.
results_summary: CQR-300 treatment reduced body weight, blood glucose, and insulin levels, improved glucose tolerance, decreased liver lipid accumulation, and inhibited gluconeogenesis, lipogenesis, and oxidative stress-related factors.
population_specificity: Leptin receptor-mutated db/db mice (n = 6/group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Cissus quadrangularis powder as a natural additive on the composition, quality, and sensory attributes of Tteokgalbi.
results_summary: Cissus quadrangularis altered moisture, protein, fat, and carbohydrate content, improved antioxidant properties, and affected color, texture, and storage characteristics, with higher doses showing reduced microbial counts after 11 days.
population_specificity: Tteokgalbi (a traditional Korean meat-based dish)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antibacterial activity of Cissus quadrangularis (CQ) against the periodontal pathogen Porphyromonas gingivalis.
results_summary: The ethanolic extract of CQ mixed with 10% DMSO showed higher inhibition against P. gingivalis compared to the aqueous extract. Both extracts displayed a minimal inhibitory concentration (MIC) of 500 µg/mL, with the ethanolic extract demonstrating superior efficacy (IC50 of 194.36 µg/mL).
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on P. gingivalis).
effective_dosage: 500 µg/mL (MIC for both extracts); IC50 of 194.36 µg/mL for ethanolic extract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a novel drug delivery system (CQ-SEDDS) to improve the oral bioavailability of Cissus quadrangularis for osteoporosis treatment.
results_summary: The CQ-SEDDS formulation enhanced bioavailability by 76%, improved absorption through lymphatic pathways, and showed potential in osteoporotic rat models. The study demonstrated significant improvements in osteoblastic differentiation and mineralization.
population_specificity: Osteoporotic rat models

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the genomic mechanisms behind Cissus quadrangularis's drought adaptation and photosynthesis transition, particularly focusing on its CAM pathway and tetraploidization.
results_summary: The study identified a high-quality genome of C. quadrangularis, revealing its tetraploidization event (~8.9 million years ago) and dominant subgenome role in drought tolerance. Transcriptome data highlighted enriched pathways (cutin, suberine, wax metabolism) in stems during drought, and stem-biased CAM-related gene expression patterns.
population_specificity: Genomic and transcriptomic analysis of Cissus quadrangularis (plant species).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the curative effect of Cissus quadrangularis on acetaminophen-induced liver injury in mice.
results_summary: Cissus quadrangularis significantly reduced body weight loss, serum alanine aminotransferase activity, bilirubin levels, and oxidative stress markers while improving liver histology in acetaminophen-treated mice.
population_specificity: Mice with acetaminophen-induced liver injury.
effective_dosage: 50 and 100 mg/kg, administered orally once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Cissus quadrangularis (CQ)-loaded chitosan-based bilayer wound dressings for wound healing applications, focusing on antibacterial, anti-inflammatory, and tissue regeneration effects.
results_summary: The study found that CQ extract released from bilayer dressings exhibited antibacterial activity against Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacteria, promoted cell proliferation, enhanced wound healing, and increased collagen deposition. The bilayer dressing also demonstrated ideal water vapor permeability and sustained CQ release over 4 days.
population_specificity: In vitro studies using NIH/3T3 and HS2 cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether a combination of Cissus Quadrangularis and Dalbergia sissoo (Tablet Reunion) improves maxillofacial fracture healing compared to a control group and a teriparatide group.
results_summary: Group 2 (Tablet Reunion) showed early pain relief, though insignificant, while Group 3 (teriparatide) demonstrated the highest bite force restoration. Radiographic healing showed no significant difference among groups, but serum ALP increased significantly in Group 3.
population_specificity: 24 patients with mandibular fractures, with or without concomitant maxillofacial fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the osteogenic potential of Cissus quadrangularis hydrogel in enhancing osseointegration of titanium implants in a rabbit model.
results_summary: The study found that Cissus quadrangularis-coated implants showed significantly increased bone area fraction occupancy (BAFO) in the femur but not in the tibia, while bone-to-implant contact (BIC) values did not differ significantly between coated and uncoated implants. The authors concluded that the hydrogel coating enhances osseointegration, though further studies are needed.
population_specificity: Adult male New Zealand white rabbits

study_goal: To determine the effect of 24 weeks of Cissus quadrangularis (CQ) treatment on delaying bone loss and its safety in postmenopausal women with osteopenia.
results_summary: CQ showed no significant change in bone mineral density (BMD) compared to placebo but reduced bone remodeling activity, as indicated by lower bone turnover markers (BTMs). Adverse events did not differ between CQ and placebo groups.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women (aged >40, no period for 1-10 years) with osteopenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the adiponectin mimetic activity of Cissus quadrangularis extract (EECQ) in mitigating insulin resistance, hyperlipidemia, and abnormal weight gain in peri-/post-menopausal rats.
results_summary: EECQ treatment protected against insulin resistance, hyperlipidemia, and abnormal weight gain in menopausal rats by upregulating AdipoR1 and restoring normal expression of downstream markers like APPL1, IRS1, Akt1, and GLUT4. The extract showed strong binding affinity to AdipoR1, comparable to the ligand adipoRon.
population_specificity: Peri-/post-menopausal rats (induced by high-fat diet and either 4-vinylcyclohexenediepoxide or bilateral ovariectomy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of ethanolic extract of Cissus quadrangularis (EECQ) on diabetic cardiomyopathy (DCM) induced by a high-fat diet and streptozotocin in rats.
results_summary: EECQ improved glucose and insulin tolerance, reduced hypercholesteremia, attenuated cardiac dysfunction and biomarkers (CKMB, LDH), decreased hypertrophic biomarkers (ANP, BNP), and alleviated oxidative stress, ROS production, and cardiac inflammation.
population_specificity: Rats with high-fat diet/streptozotocin-induced diabetic cardiomyopathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antihypertensive and vasorelaxant effects of Cissus quadrangularis in hypertensive rats, focusing on its impact on blood pressure, vascular function, and related biomarkers.
results_summary: The study found that Cissus quadrangularis extract reduced blood pressure, improved vascular relaxation, restored nitric oxide levels, and reduced oxidative stress and inflammation in hypertensive rats.
population_specificity: Male spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHR), with normotensive Wistar rats as controls.
effective_dosage: 200 mg/kg of ethanolic extract of Cissus quadrangularis (EECQ).

study_goal: To investigate the potential of rectal suppositories containing Cissus Quadrangularis and Acmella paniculata extracts in alleviating hemorrhoidal symptoms compared to a commercial hydrocortisone-cinchocaine suppository.
results_summary: The CQ-AP suppository showed comparable efficacy to the commercial suppository in reducing bleeding, prolapse size, and anal pain, with a better safety profile and lower incidence of adverse events. Patient satisfaction and preference for further use were similar between both groups.
population_specificity: Hemorrhoid outpatients (n=105) with severity grades I-III from eight hospitals in northern Thailand.
effective_dosage: One suppository administered rectally twice daily (morning and bedtime).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the protective effect of ethanolic extract of Cissus quadrangularis (EECQ) against high-fat diet/streptozotocin-induced diabetic nephropathy in rats.
results_summary: EECQ treatment significantly reduced insulin resistance, improved lipid profile and creatinine levels, restored albuminuria and glomerular filtration rate, and mitigated oxidative damage and renal inflammation. It also modulated SIRT1, DNMT1, and SOD levels, and reduced renal fibrosis markers.
population_specificity: Rats with HFD/STZ-induced diabetic nephropathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-adipogenic potential of the n-butanol fraction of Cissus quadrangularis (CQ-B) on 3T3-L1 mouse preadipocyte cell line and identify its active compounds for obesity treatment.
results_summary: The study found that CQ-B significantly downregulated lipogenic marker genes and reduced neutral lipid content in differentiated cells. Thirteen compounds with anti-adipogenic activity were identified through GC-MS analysis.
population_specificity: 3T3-L1 mouse preadipocyte cell line

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Cissus Quadrangularis on obesity, lipolysis, and browning of human white adipocytes.
results_summary: CQ significantly reduced waist and hip circumferences in obese humans and enhanced UCP1 mRNA expression in human white adipocytes, suggesting it promotes browning. Glycerol release was reduced in CQ-treated adipocytes, and UCP1 expression increased dose-dependently compared to pioglitazone.
population_specificity: Obese humans and human white adipocytes (in vitro).
effective_dosage: 10, 100, and 1000 ng/ml (in vitro); human dosage not specified.
study_duration: 8 weeks (human study); in vitro duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the osteogenic and mechanical effects of Cissus Quadrangularis extract when used as a coating on 3D-printed β-tricalcium phosphate scaffolds for bone tissue engineering.
results_summary: The study found that Cissus Quadrangularis extract, combined with polydopamine coating, significantly enhanced osteoblast proliferation, alkaline phosphatase expression, and early bone formation in vitro and in vivo, while maintaining scaffold mechanical strength.
population_specificity: Rat distal femur model (in vivo) and osteoblast cultures (in vitro).
study_duration: 4 weeks post-op (in vivo); 3 days (in vitro proliferation assessment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the active compounds in Cissus Quadrangularis responsible for bone formation and assess their biological effects on osteoblast activity.
results_summary: The study found that the ethanolic fraction (P2) enriched with rutin and quercetin significantly enhanced alkaline phosphatase activity, activated osteoprotegerin (OPG), and inhibited RANKL expression, indicating potential for promoting bone formation and inhibiting resorption. Hydroxyproline levels slightly increased with crude ethanol extract (P1), while osteocalcin was inhibited.
population_specificity: Human osteoblast cell line (MG-63)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Cissus quadrangularis (CQ) has bone-protective properties and to elucidate its mechanism of action in preventing ovariectomy-induced bone loss.
results_summary: CQ protected bone mass and microarchitecture in long bones, increased osteocalcin expression, decreased bone resorption markers, and modulated BMP and Wnt signaling pathways. It also elevated estradiol levels and influenced inflammatory markers, suggesting potential benefits for postmenopausal osteoporosis without reported side effects.
population_specificity: Female Sprague Dawley rats (ovariectomized and sham-operated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the potential of chemically treated Cissus quadrangularis fibers as reinforcing materials in polymer composites by evaluating their mechanical properties.
results_summary: Chemically treated Cissus quadrangularis fibers (5% MgCO3) showed improved tensile strength (4-24% over NaOH-treated and untreated fibers) and enhanced Young's modulus, tensile, and flexural strength (8%, 27%, and 16%, respectively) in composites with 30% fiber volume. No notable improvement was observed in impact strength.
population_specificity: Not applicable (material science study, no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-obesity activity and mechanism of action of Cissus quadrangularis extract (CQR-300) in 3T3-L1 adipocytes.
results_summary: CQR-300 inhibited lipid accumulation without cytotoxicity, down-regulated adipogenesis/lipogenesis-related genes and proteins, and up-regulated p-AMPK expression, suggesting potential anti-obesity effects.
population_specificity: 3T3-L1 adipocytes (in vitro cell line study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anxiolytic and antiepileptic effects of Cissus quadrangularis aqueous extract, including its antioxidant properties and GABAergic neurotransmission involvement.
results_summary: The extract significantly and dose-dependently reduced seizure activity, increased latency to seizures, and demonstrated anxiolytic effects in epileptic mice. It also lowered oxidative stress markers (MDA, GABA-T) and increased protective factors (GSH, GABA).
population_specificity: Epileptic mice induced by pilocarpine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the osteoblast differentiation and mineralization potential of ethyl acetate (CQ-EA) and butanol (CQ-B) extracts of Cissus quadrangularis on mouse pre-osteoblast cells to identify an antiosteoporotic compound.
results_summary: Both CQ-EA and CQ-B extracts were nontoxic at high concentrations (100 µg/ml) and enhanced cell proliferation at low concentrations (0.1 µg/ml and 1 µg/ml). They upregulated osteoblast differentiation and mineralization markers, with CQ-EA showing earlier and more potent effects than CQ-B.
population_specificity: Mouse pre-osteoblast cell line MC3T3-E1 (sub-clone 4).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to confirm the efficacy of CQR-300 in reducing body fat percentage and improving metabolic syndrome-related blood parameters in overweight individuals.
results_summary: CQR-300 significantly reduced body fat (8.9% by impedance, 12.8% by DEXA), improved lipid profiles, blood pressure, glucose, leptin, and adiponectin levels compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Overweight individuals (67 participants, 35 in CQR-300 group, 32 in placebo group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness of Cissus quadrangularis (CQ) in promoting osteoblast differentiation in murine pre-osteoblast cells (MC3T3-E1).
results_summary: Lower concentrations of CQ-E (0.1 and 1 µg/ml) were non-toxic, increased cell proliferation, and enhanced osteoblast differentiation, while higher concentrations (>10 µg/ml) had adverse effects. The study demonstrated dose-dependent anabolic and osteogenic properties of CQ-E.
population_specificity: Murine pre-osteoblast cell line (MC3T3-E1).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Cissus quadrangularis stem fraction (CQSF) on hyperglycemia-mediated oxidative stress and inflammatory responses in diabetic rats.
results_summary: CQSF administration significantly reversed diabetes-induced increases in blood glucose, inflammatory markers, and oxidative stress, while restoring antioxidant enzyme activities and histopathological alterations in the liver and pancreas. The effects were comparable to the standard drug metformin.
population_specificity: Nicotinamide/streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats
effective_dosage: 100 mg/kg body weight, daily oral dose

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-cancer potential of Cissus quadrangularis ethanolic extract on KB oral epidermoid cancer cells through in vitro and in silico analysis.
results_summary: The study found that Cissus quadrangularis extract induced apoptosis and G1 phase cell cycle arrest in KB cells, increased ROS liberation, altered mitochondrial membrane potential, upregulated p53, and downregulated Bcl-2. In silico analysis suggested the extract's active constituents bind Bcl-2 with higher affinity than p53, supporting its apoptotic effects.
population_specificity: KB oral epidermoid cancer cell line (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-arthritic activity of Cissus quadrangularis hydroalcoholic extract (CQHE) and explore its mechanism of action.
results_summary: CQHE showed dose-dependent inhibition of joint swelling in arthritis models, reduced serum TNF-α levels, oxidative stress, and synovial expression of inflammatory markers. Chronic administration of CQHE did not cause physiological or pathological changes, indicating safety.
population_specificity: Rats with formaldehyde-induced and adjuvant-induced arthritis.
study_duration: 28 days for toxicity study; joint swelling measured on days 8, 9, 10 (formaldehyde) and 3, 7, 14, 21 (adjuvant).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Cissus quadrangularis stem extract (CQSF) on carbohydrate metabolism in diabetic rats to assess its antidiabetic potential.
results_summary: CQSF significantly reduced blood glucose levels by 56% at 100 mg/kg, modulated key carbohydrate-metabolizing enzymes, and increased hepatic glycogen content. The extract contained 10 chemical constituents, with N-methyl-1-adamantane acetamide being the most prevalent.
population_specificity: Experimental diabetic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the cellular and molecular mechanisms by which Cissus Quadrangularis and Withania somnifera exert chondroprotective and bone regenerative effects in osteoarthritis and osteogenesis.
results_summary: Cissus Quadrangularis reduced IL-1β-induced toxicity, upregulated cell growth, inhibited cartilage-destructive cytokines and matrix metalloproteinases, and enhanced survivin expression via p38 MAPK inhibition. In osteotomized rats, it significantly improved alkaline phosphatase and cartilage tissue formation compared to controls and other treatments.
population_specificity: Human chondrocytes (in vitro) and osteotomized rats (in vivo).
study_duration: 36 hours (in vitro); duration in vivo not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective role of petroleum ether extract of Cissus quadrangularis (PECQ) against diabetes-induced delayed fetal skeletal ossification in rats.
results_summary: PECQ pretreatment significantly restored ossification centers and improved ossification extent in forelimb and hindlimb bones of neonatal pups from diabetic rats compared to untreated diabetic controls. The results suggest PECQ is effective against diabetes-induced delayed fetal skeletal ossification.
population_specificity: Pregnant Wistar rats with streptozotocin-induced diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Cissus quadrangularis (CQE) could mitigate oxidative stress and restore steroidogenesis impaired by quinalphos-induced toxicity in mice.
results_summary: CQE significantly recovered antioxidant profiles, reduced lipid peroxidation, and restored mRNA expression levels of steroidogenic enzymes, effectively protecting against oxidative stress and preventing male infertility.
population_specificity: Male mice exposed to quinalphos-induced toxicity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of PECQ on osteopenia development in a type 1 diabetic rat model and compare its effects to insulin treatment.
results_summary: PECQ treatment significantly prevented cortical and trabecular bone thickness loss and improved bone strength in diabetic rats, comparable to insulin. It also improved serum ALP levels and reduced TRAP and hydroxyproline levels, though it did not affect glycemic levels.
population_specificity: Type 1 diabetic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the therapeutic effects of Cissus quadrangularis supplementation on joint pain in exercise-trained men.
results_summary: Cissus quadrangularis supplementation significantly reduced joint pain, as measured by the WOMAC Index (~31% improvement), but did not significantly impact clinical measures like heart rate or blood biomarkers.
population_specificity: 29 healthy, exercise-trained men aged 20-46 with chronic joint pain from strenuous exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Cissus Quadrangularis (Asthi Shrinkhala) in combination with Majja Basti for bone strengthening in osteoporosis patients.
results_summary: The study reported encouraging results in 12 patients treated with Majja Basti and Cissus Quadrangularis pulp capsules, suggesting potential benefits for bone health. However, the small sample size and lack of detailed statistical analysis limit definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: 12 patients with osteoporosis (Asthi-Majjakshaya in Ayurveda).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-cancer activity of Cissus quadrangularis (CQ) extracts, particularly against skin epidermoid carcinoma (A431 cell line).
results_summary: The acetone extract of CQ demonstrated significant anti-cancer activity in A431 cells, with a GI(50) value of 8 μg/mL, while its purified fraction (AFCQ) showed even greater potency (GI(50) = 4.8 μg/mL). AFCQ induced apoptosis in A431 cells, comparable to the standard drug Doxorubicin, as evidenced by apoptotic markers like Bax-Bcl-2 ratio and cytochrome c release.
population_specificity: In vitro study using human skin epidermoid carcinoma (A431) cell line.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the protective role of Cissus quadrangularis ethanol extract (CQE) and its constituents (quercetin and resveratrol) against oxidative stress in endothelial cells.
results_summary: CQE, quercetin, and resveratrol reduced ROS levels and increased antioxidant enzyme expression (Cu/Zn-SOD, Mn-SOD, GPx, eNOS) in H2O2-injured endothelial cells without causing DNA damage.
population_specificity: Human umbilical vein endothelial ECV304 cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the osteogenic effects of Cissus Quadrangularis (Harjor) with other herbal agents and a placebo in mandibular fracture healing.
results_summary: Cissus Quadrangularis showed moderate efficacy in reducing pain, swelling, tenderness, and mobility compared to the placebo, though less than Osteoseal. It also contributed to increased serum calcium and phosphorus levels, unlike the placebo.
population_specificity: Patients with mandibular fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiosteoporotic effects of a phytoestrogen-rich fraction (IND-HE) derived from Cissus Quadrangularis in ovariectomized rats.
results_summary: IND-HE (75 and 100 mg/kg) significantly increased bone thickness, density, hardness, serum estradiol, vitamin D3, and calcium while reducing alkaline phosphatase, demonstrating antiosteoporotic activity comparable to estrogen treatment.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized female Wistar rats (n=6 per group).
effective_dosage: 75 mg/kg and 100 mg/kg orally once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of petroleum ether extract of Cissus quadrangularis (CQ) in preventing osteopenia in ovariectomized Wistar rats.
results_summary: CQ significantly increased cortical and trabecular bone thickness, comparable to raloxifene, and showed anti-osteoporotic activity by reducing serum ALP, TRAP, and hydroxyproline levels.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized female Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential adverse effects and genotoxicity of Cissus quadrangularis extract (CQR-300) in subchronic toxicity studies.
results_summary: The study found no treatment-related toxicity, mortality, or significant changes in clinical, hematological, or histopathological parameters at doses up to 2500 mg/kg bw/day. Genotoxicity tests (Ames assay, chromosomal aberration, micronucleus assay) also showed no adverse effects.
population_specificity: Sprague Dawley rats (20/sex/group)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Cissus quadrangularis on the regulation of IGF system components in human osteoblast-like SaOS-2 cells.
results_summary: The study found that Cissus quadrangularis increased mRNA expression of IGF-I, IGF-II, and IGF-IR, as well as protein levels of IGF-IR and IGF-I, IGF-II, and IGFBP-3 in the conditioned medium, indicating positive regulation of the IGF system components.
population_specificity: Human osteoblast-like SaOS-2 cells

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and side effects of Cissus quadrangularis and a flavanoid mixture versus placebo in treating acute hemorrhoidal symptoms.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in symptom improvement between Cissus quadrangularis, the flavanoid mixture, and placebo, suggesting none were effective for early hemorrhoidal symptoms. No adverse events or blood chemistry changes were reported.
population_specificity: Acute hemorrhoidal patients (570 participants: 299 females, 271 males) from three hospitals.
effective_dosage: 3 x 2 p.c. for 4 days, then 2 x 2 p.c. for 3 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of ethanolic extract of Cissus quadrangularis on the proliferation, differentiation, and matrix mineralization of human osteoblast-like SaOS-2 cells.
results_summary: The study found that Cissus quadrangularis increased DNA synthesis, matrix mineralization, and the expression of Runx2 in SaOS-2 cells, indicating enhanced osteoblast proliferation and differentiation. The extract was also shown to be non-toxic to osteoblastic cells.
population_specificity: Human osteoblast-like SaOS-2 cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anti-inflammatory activity and molecular mechanism of the ethyl acetate extract of Cissus quadrangularis stem (CQE) in LPS-stimulated RAW 264.7 macrophage cells.
results_summary: CQE inhibited LPS-induced nitric oxide production and suppressed iNOS expression and NF-κB nuclear translocation. It also induced HO-1 expression, and its anti-inflammatory effects were partially reversed by an HO-1 inhibitor.
population_specificity: RAW 264.7 macrophage cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the estrogenic activity and effects on sexual behavior of IND-HE (a friedelin-rich fraction of Cissus Quadrangularis) in ovariectomized female Wistar rats.
results_summary: IND-HE (75 and 100 mg/kg) improved sexual behavior parameters, significantly reducing darting and hopping latency while increasing darting and hopping frequency. It also demonstrated estrogenic activity, evidenced by vaginal cornification, increased uterine weight, and elevated serum estrogen levels.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized female Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate the anti-osteoporotic effects of the petroleum ether extract of Cissus quadrangularis in ovariectomy-induced osteoporosis in rats.
results_summary: Cissus quadrangularis significantly increased the force required to break the femur and improved cortical and trabecular bone thickness, with effects comparable to raloxifene.
population_specificity: Female Wistar rats with ovariectomy-induced osteoporosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of petroleum-ether extract of Cissus quadrangularis on bone loss in an osteoporotic rat model induced by ovariectomy.
results_summary: The study found that Cissus quadrangularis extract reduced bone loss, increased femur weight, and decreased osteoclastic activity while promoting bone formation, comparable to the effects of raloxifene. The extract's activity was confirmed through TRAP and ALP staining, suggesting potential for osteoporosis treatment.
population_specificity: Female Wistar rats (ovariectomized to model postmenopausal osteoporosis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Cissus quadrangularis on bone marrow mesenchymal stem cell proliferation, differentiation into osteoblasts, and extracellular matrix calcification, as well as its additive effects with osteogenic media.
results_summary: Cissus quadrangularis enhanced osteoblast differentiation and extracellular matrix calcification at doses of 100, 200, and 300 µg/mL, with the highest dose also increasing cell proliferation. Combining it with osteogenic media further improved proliferation, differentiation, and calcification compared to controls.
population_specificity: Bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Cissus quadrangularis ethanol extract (CQ-E) on osteoblast differentiation and function, focusing on its potential role in bone healing.
results_summary: The study found that CQ-E significantly increased alkaline phosphatase (ALP) activity and mineralized nodules in murine osteoblastic cells, suggesting enhanced osteoblastic activity. The effect on ALP activity appeared to be mediated by the MAPK pathway, particularly p38 MAPK.
population_specificity: Murine osteoblastic cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of bovine-derived hydroxyapatite combined with Cissus quadrangularis versus hydroxyapatite alone in treating intrabony defects.
results_summary: Both treatments showed favorable clinical results, but no statistically significant differences were found between the groups. The composite graft (HA + CQ) trended toward better performance but lacked statistical significance.
population_specificity: Twenty patients with one intrabony defect each.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the gastroprotective effects of Cissus quadrangularis extract (CQE) against aspirin-induced gastric ulcers in rats.
results_summary: CQE significantly reduced gastric mucosal lesions, decreased gastric toxicity, and restored depleted levels of glycoproteins, gastric wall mucus, and non-protein sulphydryls (NPSH) in ulcerated rats. Histological studies confirmed these protective effects.
population_specificity: Rats with aspirin-induced gastric ulcers (pyloric ligated model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of a Cissus quadrangularis formulation in managing metabolic syndrome, particularly weight loss and central obesity.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant reductions in weight, central obesity, fasting blood glucose, total cholesterol, LDL-cholesterol, triglycerides, and C-reactive protein in participants who received the Cissus quadrangularis formulation, regardless of diet.
population_specificity: 123 overweight and obese individuals (47.2% male, 52.8% female; ages 19-50).
effective_dosage: Two daily doses (exact amount not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the analgesic, anti-inflammatory, and venotonic effects of Cissus quadrangularis (CQ) methanol extract in comparison to reference drugs, particularly for treating hemorrhoid-related symptoms.
results_summary: CQ demonstrated significant peripheral and central analgesic activity, reduced inflammation in acute phase models, and exhibited venotonic effects similar to a bioflavonoid mixture, supporting its traditional use for hemorrhoid treatment.
population_specificity: Mice and rats (animal models) and isolated human umbilical vein tissue.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiulcer effects of Cissus quadrangularis ethanol extract (CQE) against aspirin-induced gastric toxicity in rats.
results_summary: CQE at 500 mg/kg showed significant gastroprotective effects (71.2% ulcer protection), comparable to ranitidine (71.9%), likely due to antioxidant activity and reduced oxidative damage and neutrophil infiltration.
population_specificity: Rats with aspirin-induced gastric ulcers
effective_dosage: 250, 500, and 750 mg/kg (500 mg/kg was the optimal dose)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of citric acid as a pretreatment agent for improving dewatering efficiency in aged oily sludge (AOS) and to investigate its dewatering mechanism.
results_summary: Citric acid pretreatment reduced the moisture content of AOS from 80.12% to 71.69% under pressure filtration, and electro-dewatering further lowered it to 47.36%. The study highlighted the roles of surfactants, electric field forces, pH, and temperature in the dewatering process.
population_specificity: Aged oily sludge (AOS) samples.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how varying the concentration ratio of citric acid to acetic acid in chitosan films could control mechanical properties and drug release.
results_summary: Increasing citric acid concentration enhanced drug release, while higher drying temperatures reduced it. Structural changes in the films allowed control over tensile strength and strain, and a visual indicator for drug release was developed.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on chitosan films).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an anaerobic hybrid reactor (AHR) in treating high-COD and high-TVA citric acid production wastewater.
results_summary: The AHR achieved 90% COD removal efficiency, 0.25 Nm3 CH4/kg COD methane yield, and 65% methane content at an OLR of 7.6 kg COD/m3/d. Bioaugmentation with syntrophic methanogenic consortia (SMC) successfully recovered the system after TVA accumulation at higher OLR.
population_specificity: Citric acid production wastewater

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of citric acid, synbiotics, and probiotics administered through drinking water on broiler growth performance, carcass characteristics, and blood biochemical profiles.
results_summary: Citric acid showed modest improvements in growth performance metrics compared to the control group, but the probiotic group outperformed it significantly in body weight, weight gain, and feed conversion ratio. Biochemical parameters like cholesterol and LDL levels were also affected, though citric acid's impact was less pronounced than probiotics.
population_specificity: One-day-old Cobb 500 broiler chicks (400 total, divided into groups).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but metrics were recorded weekly until the end of the trial (duration unclear).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of citric acid on the surface properties and biofilm removal efficacy of denture base acrylic resin compared to other denture cleansers.
results_summary: Citric acid significantly increased surface hydrophilicity without affecting roughness, microhardness, or color stability, and demonstrated superior biofilm disruption, reducing microbial viability, metabolic activity, and biofilm dry weight more effectively than other cleansers.
population_specificity: Conventional, heat-processed denture base acrylic resin disks (in vitro study).
study_duration: Evaluated at baseline (T0), after 5 minutes (T1), and after 1 week (T2) of exposure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a mixture of citric acid and dextrose could inhibit the growth of Avian Pathogenic Escherichia coli (APEC) in laying hens to control colibacillosis cases.
results_summary: The study found that the citric acid and dextrose mixture led to a significant decrease in the appearance of intestinal villi, suggesting potential harm at the tested doses. Higher concentrations (T1) showed worse outcomes, while lower concentrations (T3) showed slight improvement, indicating the need for further research with lower doses.
population_specificity: Laying hens infected with APEC in Indonesia.
effective_dosage: 1 g/1.25 L, 1 g/2.5 L, and 1 g/3.75 L of drinking water.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether citric acid (CA) could enhance the foaming properties of egg white protein (EWP) to improve the 3D printing fidelity of meringues.
results_summary: CA increased EWP viscosity, hydrophobic group exposure, and free sulfhydryl content, improving foaminess and structural stability, which enhanced 3D printing fidelity. The treated EWP showed suitable viscosity, shear thinning, and elasticity for high-quality printed samples.
population_specificity: Egg white protein (EWP) in a food science context (no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of combining citric acid with phages to control Vibrio parahaemolyticus growth in seafood.
results_summary: The study found that combining phages with citric acid significantly reduced V. parahaemolyticus levels in salmon fillets and biofilm formation, with the highest reduction achieved using phage VPpYZU64 and 600 μg/mL citric acid.
population_specificity: Vibrio parahaemolyticus in salmon fillets stored at 25 °C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of citric acid on the chemical composition, fermentation quality, microbial communities, and metabolic pathways of sugarcane tops silage with varying water-soluble carbohydrate contents before and after aerobic exposure.
results_summary: Citric acid improved silage quality by reducing dry matter loss, inhibiting undesirable microbes like enterobacteria and yeast, and modulating microbial metabolic pathways. It also maintained stable propionic acid, butyric acid, and ethanol levels during aerobic exposure.
population_specificity: Sugarcane tops silage (STS) with high and low water-soluble carbohydrate (WSC) contents.
study_duration: 125 days of ensiling followed by 4, 8, and 16 days of aerobic exposure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of citric acid (CA) and natural deep eutectic solvents (NADES) in extracting pectin from apple waste, focusing on yield, chemical properties, and thermal stability.
results_summary: Citric acid extraction yielded higher pectin amounts (≈11 g/100 g CA) compared to NADES (≈4 g/100 g CA), but NADES-extracted pectin showed greater thermal stability and different structural properties. Ultrasound-assisted NADES extraction improved yield (13-18 g/100 g) and purity while preserving bioactive components like rhamnogalacturonan I (RG-I).
population_specificity: Apple waste (pulp and peel) from Malus domestica.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 2% citric acid ointment could effectively control infections and promote healthy granulation tissue in chronic wounds.
results_summary: The study found that 2% citric acid ointment successfully controlled infections and facilitated healthy granulation tissue formation in all 24 cases, despite antibiotic resistance in most bacterial isolates. The treatment was effective after 3 to 20 applications.
population_specificity: 24 cases of chronic wounds with large raw areas unresponsive to conventional therapy for over 3 weeks.
study_duration: 3 to 20 applications (duration per application not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate how citric acid (CA) reinforces chemically treated hair and understand its mechanisms of action.
results_summary: CA treatment improved hair structural integrity, increasing crosslinking density, tensile elastic modulus (7.5%-23.5%), and fatigue resistance (56%-124%). It also reduced calcium levels (21%-42%) and crystallized calcium soaps.
population_specificity: Chemically treated hair (high-lift bleached, middle-lift bleached, permanently colored, and permed and colored hair).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Cissus quadrangularis petroleum ether extract on fetal bone development during intra-uterine growth in rats.
results_summary: The study found that maternal administration of Cissus quadrangularis extract significantly increased the percentage of ossified cartilage (bone) in newborn pups compared to the control group, indicating enhanced fetal bone growth. The results were statistically significant (P<0.001-0.0001).
population_specificity: Pregnant rats and their newborn pups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the ulcer-protective effects and healing mechanisms of a methanolic extract of Cissus quadrangularis (CQE) in gastric ulcers.
results_summary: CQE demonstrated comparable ulcer-protective effects to sucralfate, significantly enhancing mucosal defensive factors like mucin secretion, glycoproteins, and cell proliferation, suggesting it strengthens mucosal resistance and promotes healing.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal model based on dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of citric acid (CA), alone and in combination with sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS), in eliminating Salmonella biofilms in hydroponic agriculture systems.
results_summary: The study found that 1% CA alone achieved a 1.4 ± 0.3 log reduction in Salmonella biofilms, but when combined with 0.1% SDS, it reduced biofilm levels to below detectable limits (>5.6 log reduction). Confocal microscopy confirmed significantly higher proportions of damaged/dead cells in the combined treatment (82.6 ± 2.6%) compared to single treatments.
population_specificity: Polyvinyl chloride pipes in hydroponic systems contaminated with Salmonella biofilms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether citric acid could improve the physicochemical stability of lifitegrast in an eyedrop formulation by preventing oxidative degradation.
results_summary: The study found that citric acid effectively protected lifitegrast from oxidative stress, contributing to the stability of the eyedrop formulation under accelerated conditions. All critical quality attributes, including drug content and impurities, remained stable.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro/formulation study)
study_duration: Accelerated storage conditions (specific duration not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of CABR (Citric Acid-Based Residue) on growth performance, carcass yield, and meat composition in Thai broiler chickens.
results_summary: The study found that 3% and 6% CABR improved growth performance (body weight gain and feed conversion ratio) without negatively affecting meat or carcass quality, while 12% CABR reduced dressing percentage but did not harm organ weights or meat quality.
population_specificity: Thai broiler chickens (KKU 1), one-day-old mixed-sex chicks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of citric acid (0.2-0.8 M) versus acid-free hydrothermal processing in depectinating blackcurrant pomace and subsequent defibrillation for material applications.
results_summary: Citric acid effectively depectinated blackcurrant pomace but resulted in lower thermal stability (322-325 °C) compared to acid-free processing (345-348 °C). The defibrillated materials showed potential for hydrogel formation after bleaching, indicating citric acid's role in modifying lignocellulosic properties.
population_specificity: Blackcurrant pomace (plant-based material)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the synergistic antibacterial activity and mechanism of citric acid (CA) combined with Echinacea purpurea extract (EE) against Cronobacter sakazakii.
results_summary: The combination of CA (pH 3.0) and EE effectively inactivated C. sakazakii, causing cell membrane damage, hyperpolarization, and increased permeability, leading to bacterial death. The treatment also showed strong disinfectant efficacy on various surfaces.
population_specificity: Cronobacter sakazakii isolated from powdered infant formula (PIF).
study_duration: 30 minutes for bacterial inactivation, 15 minutes for surface disinfection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of citric acid (as part of the SorCA resin) combined with tripotassium citrate (TPC) as a fire retardant in wood modification.
results_summary: The combination of SorCA and TPC showed high weight percent gain but faced challenges in fixation stability and flame retardancy post-leaching. While TPC exhibited high flame retardancy initially, its efficacy decreased after leaching, though Bunsen burner tests indicated some retained performance.
population_specificity: Scots Pine (Pinus sylvestris L.) wood specimens.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether citric acid-linked chitosan biofunctionalized 3D-printed PLA scaffolds could enhance osteogenic and antibacterial properties for orthopedic applications.
results_summary: The study found that citric acid-linked chitosan scaffolds demonstrated significant antibacterial activity against E. coli and S. aureus and promoted osteogenic activity in MG-63 cells compared to unmodified PLA scaffolds.
population_specificity: In vitro study using MG-63 cells and bacterial cultures (E. coli and S. aureus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms by which citric acid (CA) mitigates cadmium (Cd) toxicity in Brassica napus and enhances phytoremediation processes.
results_summary: CA application significantly improved plant physiological attributes, Cd detoxification, and tolerance by modulating key genes involved in photosynthesis and Cd transport. It increased Cd accumulation in stems and leaves, enhanced phytochelatins and metallothioneins, and reduced oxidative stress markers, leading to improved plant biomass and Cd tolerance.
population_specificity: Brassica napus (rapeseed) plants grown in Cd-contaminated growth medium.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fermenting citric acid by-products with Bacillus subtilis I9 could improve their nutritional quality for animal feed.
results_summary: Fermentation with B. subtilis I9 significantly reduced crude fiber, hemicellulose, and cellulose while increasing crude protein and amino acid content, enhancing the nutritional profile of citric acid by-products for animal feed.
population_specificity: Citric acid by-products (animal feed substrate)
effective_dosage: Inoculation with B. subtilis I9 at 10^7 CFU/mL

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of citric acid-functionalized copper-doped biochar nanocomposite as a sensor for detecting uric acid.
results_summary: The study found that the citric acid-functionalized nanozyme effectively catalyzed the oxidation of TMB and detected uric acid with high selectivity and sensitivity, achieving a detection range of 1-90 μM. The sensor demonstrated strong performance under optimized conditions, with an R² of 0.997.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: Not applicable (functionalization component, not a dosage study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether citric acid treatment could effectively manage refractory chronic postoperative wounds in a breast carcinoma patient, avoiding major reconstructive surgery.
results_summary: The study found that citric acid treatment promoted faster granulation and epithelialization, leading to acceptable wound healing without disrupting chemotherapy cycles and avoiding the need for major reconstructive surgery.
population_specificity: A single surgical case of breast carcinoma with a refractory chronic postoperative raw area.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a citric acid modulation strategy to enhance the degradation of levofloxacin in wastewater using magnetic composites combined with dielectric barrier discharge.
results_summary: Citric acid modulation improved charge migration, increasing levofloxacin degradation from 78.2% to 98.6% and reducing energy efficiency. The composite effectively utilized active substances from plasma, with 1O2 and ·O2- playing key roles.
population_specificity: Wastewater treatment (no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether citric acid could improve the properties of wheat straw pulp fibers for sustainable material production.
results_summary: Citric acid crosslinking improved fiber properties, reducing crystallinity and enhancing drainage performance by 21%. It also significantly increased dry and wet strength by 21% and 282%, respectively.
population_specificity: Wheat straw pulp fibers (non-human, material science application).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficiency of chemical oxygen demand (COD) removal from wastewater containing Citric Acid and electricity production using a two-chamber microbial fuel cell (MFC).
results_summary: The MFC achieved a maximum power density of 18228.10 µW/m² and current density of 244.44 mA/m², with a maximum COD removal of 72%. Grape waste significantly enhanced energy production and COD removal.
population_specificity: Citric acid factory wastewater (laboratory-scale study).
effective_dosage: Optimal conditions included MLSS 1400 mg/L, COD:TKN:P ratio 140:10:1, and grape waste dose of 1.4 g/L.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how citric acid (CA) concentrations and thermal treatments affect the performance of biobased films made from xylan and chitosan.
results_summary: The study found that thermal treatment, especially at 155°C, significantly improved water resistance, mechanical properties, and UV-blocking performance of the films. The presence of 5 wt% CA further enhanced dry and wet stress-strain values and thermal stability.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on biobased films)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to observe the effect of citric acid on the microstructure, mechanical properties, corrosion resistance, and morphology of hard anodic layers on aluminum alloys.
results_summary: The study found that citric acid, when used in combination with sulfuric acid, effectively produced hard anodic layers with improved mechanical properties and corrosion resistance, particularly in the 6061-T6 (Al-Mg-Si) alloy. The 7075-T6 (Al-Zn) alloy showed enhanced oxide formation, while the 2024-T6 (Al-Cu) alloy had the lowest performance due to high copper concentration.
population_specificity: Aluminum alloys (2024-T3, 6061-T6, 7075-T6)
effective_dosage: Different concentrations of citric-sulfuric acid mixtures (specific amounts not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anti-melanin effects of GFRS (a citric acid heat-treated product of Panax ginseng berry) and identify its active components.
results_summary: GFRS showed significant anti-melanin activity by promoting autophagy flux levels and inhibiting tyrosinase activity, with Rg3, Rg5, and Rk1 being the most effective components. Citric acid heat treatment at 100°C effectively converted ginsenoside Rd into these active ingredients.
population_specificity: Zebrafish models and in vitro assays (no human subjects specified).
effective_dosage: Not specified (only mentions heat treatment at 100°C).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if citric acid (CA) could effectively immobilize epigallocatechin gallate (EGCG) onto PET fabric to enhance hydrophilicity and UV protection.
results_summary: The study found that citric acid, combined with alkaline/DES pretreatment, significantly improved the hydrophilicity, antistatic properties, and UV protection of PET fabric, with durable effects even after multiple wash cycles.
population_specificity: Poly(ethylene terephthalate) (PET) fabric

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether citric acid treatment improves sensory quality, antioxidant activity, and storage life of sorghum seeds by analyzing phenotypic changes and regulatory mechanisms.
results_summary: Citric acid treatment significantly increased ∆a, ∆b, and ∆l values after storage, enhanced SOD, POD, and CAT enzyme activities (1.94–2.45 times higher than control), and upregulated genes in the flavonoid biosynthetic pathway, promoting flavonoid accumulation and delaying seed discoloration.
population_specificity: Sorghum seeds

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the viability and attachment of cultured Human Periodontal Ligament Cells (HPLC) on dehydrated root surfaces treated with citric acid and EDTA solutions to improve reattachment in avulsed teeth.
results_summary: Citric acid treatment for 30 minutes resulted in significantly higher viable cell intensity and total cell count compared to EDTA and control groups, demonstrating superior outcomes for periodontal ligament regeneration.
population_specificity: In-vitro study using cultured Human Periodontal Ligament Cells (HPLC) on root slices of sound human permanent teeth.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize the crosslinking of hydrogel films using citric acid (CA) and glutaraldehyde (GA) for controlled drug delivery in anti-inflammatory wound healing.
results_summary: The study found that hydrogel films crosslinked with CA and GA exhibited improved structural properties, enhanced drug absorption, and delayed release of triamcinolone acetonide (TAA), leading to better anti-inflammatory efficiency.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
study_duration: Not specified (focused on material properties and drug release within 24 h)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of citric acid pretreatment in reducing sodium content in red mud and its impact on particle size, phase, morphology, and pore size.
results_summary: Citric acid pretreatment achieved an 86.33% Na+ leaching rate under optimal conditions, dissolved red mud agglomerates and cancrinite, and formed new phases like calcium oxalate. The treatment was cost-effective and produced neutral leaching residue, aiding red mud's practical application.
population_specificity: Red mud (industrial waste from alumina production)
effective_dosage: 15% citric acid dosage, liquid-to-solid ratio of 7 mL/g

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the apical sealability of RealSeal SE sealer with 10% citric acid as an irrigant against other combinations in endodontic therapy.
results_summary: Group IV (10% citric acid + RealSeal SE) showed statistically lower mean microleakage compared to other groups, indicating better apical sealability. RealSeal SE with citric acid outperformed AH Plus groups, which showed the least sealability.
population_specificity: Single-rooted premolars (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of citric acid (CA) in a hydrogel film formulation for wound healing, particularly in diabetic wounds, by assessing its physicochemical properties and biological effects.
results_summary: The study found that citric acid, combined with pomegranate peel extract and β-cyclodextrin-carboxymethyl tapioca starch, improved wound healing by enhancing collagen deposition, reducing inflammation, and promoting cell proliferation and migration. The optimized film showed pH-dependent release of ellagic acid and demonstrated antibacterial properties.
population_specificity: Mice model (diabetic wound healing)
study_duration: Up to 24 hours (release study); wound healing effects observed over an unspecified period in mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 50% ascorbic acid and 50% citric acid solution could restore the shear bond strength of metallic brackets on bleached teeth and assess its stability and enamel etching effects.
results_summary: The combined acids restored shear bond strength to levels comparable to unbleached teeth, remained stable for up to 21 days, and provided effective enamel etching in a single step. The 5-minute application was more effective than sodium ascorbate treatment.
population_specificity: Extracted human teeth (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: 50% citric acid combined with 50% ascorbic acid, applied for 5 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how BcWCL2 regulates citrate secretion and its role in the virulence of Botrytis cinerea, including the effects of exogenous citric acid on infection processes.
results_summary: The study found that deletion of BcWCL2 reduced citrate secretion and virulence, while exogenous citric acid restored infection cushion formation, hyphal penetration, and virulence. BcWCL2 regulates Bcvel1, influencing citrate secretion, tissue acidification, and redox homeostasis.
population_specificity: Botrytis cinerea (a plant pathogenic fungus)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of 10% citric acid (CA) on root dentin mineral content and its effect on the adhesive properties of a bioceramic root canal sealer.
results_summary: The study found that 10% CA significantly altered root dentin mineral content (C, O, Ca, P, and Ca/P ratios) and improved the push-out bond strength of the bioceramic sealer compared to the control, with no significant differences between chelating agents.
population_specificity: Extracted single-rooted lower premolar teeth (n=20 in the CA group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a 20 wt% citric acid (CA) dental etching agent in promoting dentin biomimetic mineralization and improving bonding durability in resin-bonded restorations.
results_summary: The study found that CA effectively removed the smear layer, formed strong bonds with collagen fibrils, and facilitated nearly complete intrafibrillar and extrafibrillar mineralization within 24 hours. The remineralized dentin restored mechanical properties to sound dentin levels and improved bonding efficacy compared to conventional phosphate acid-etching.
population_specificity: Dental applications (dentin bonding interface in resin-bonded restorations).
effective_dosage: 20 wt% citric acid (CA) as a dental etching agent.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cervical percutaneous interferential current stimulation could improve cough reflexes in Parkinson's disease patients, using 1% citric acid as a test stimulus.
results_summary: The study found that the proportion of patients with a normal cough reflex after consuming 1% citric acid significantly increased post-intervention (p=0.001), though other indicators like tongue pressure and peak expiratory flow remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Patients with Hoehn-Yahr stages 2-4 Parkinson's disease (n=25).
effective_dosage: 1% citric acid (used as a test stimulus, not a treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a hydrogen peroxide-citric acid (HPCA) treatment for extracting cellulose from ramie bone (RB) in an environmentally friendly manner.
results_summary: The HPCA treatment successfully removed lignin and hemicellulose from RB, producing cellulose with improved crystallinity (up to 72.51%), good thermal stability, and high water/oil binding capacity. The extracted cellulose showed potential for use in food and composite materials.
population_specificity: Agricultural waste (ramie bone) from the textile industry.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether citric acid could inhibit YopH phosphatase activity in Yersinia bacteria and compare its effects to trimesic acid.
results_summary: Citric acid and trimesic acid reversibly reduced YopH enzyme activity and decreased cell viability in Jurkat and macrophage cell lines, with greater inhibition of bacterial YopH than human CD45 phosphatase. Molecular docking confirmed citric acid's binding to YopH.
population_specificity: Jurkat T E6.1 and macrophage J774.2 cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a blend of citric acid and hydrochloric acid (CP) against Salmonella and mesophilic aerobic plate counts (APC) on chicken hearts and livers.
results_summary: The study found that CP reduced Salmonella counts in chicken hearts and livers by more than one log, similar to other antimicrobials tested. All treatments minimized APC growth for up to 3 days of refrigerated storage without affecting color values.
population_specificity: Chicken hearts and livers inoculated with Salmonella.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of citric acid-autoclaving (CA-A) treatment on the physicochemical and digestive properties of native ginseng starches.
results_summary: CA-A treatment destroyed the granular morphology, crystal, and short-range ordered structure of ginseng starches, increased solubility, and promoted polymerization and recrystallization of starch molecules. It also significantly increased resistant starch (RS) content from 28.26% to 54.30%.
population_specificity: Native ginseng starches (in vitro study, no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal inclusion level of citric acid (CA) in geese diets for improving growth performance, plasma constituents, and intestinal health.
results_summary: Supplementation with 3.2% CA improved growth performance, reduced body fat, enhanced plasma antioxidant capacity, and modulated cecum microbiota by increasing beneficial bacteria and decreasing harmful bacteria.
population_specificity: 240 healthy female geese aged 28 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exogenous application of citric acid (CA) could extend the postharvest storage life of broccoli by preserving its biochemical and morphological properties.
results_summary: The study found that 1 mM CA treatment delayed weight loss, respiration rate, and color degradation in broccoli, while also maintaining higher vitamin C content. It was among the recommended treatments to minimize losses in quality during storage.
population_specificity: Postharvest broccoli samples (Brassica oleracea L. var. italica) stored under controlled conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a poly(salicylic acid)-poly(citric acid) (FPSa-PCG) hydrogel could effectively treat diabetic wounds by reducing oxidative stress and inflammation while promoting angiogenesis.
results_summary: The FPSa-PCG hydrogel demonstrated antioxidation, anti-inflammation, and macrophage phenotype regulation, enhancing wound closure in diabetic models by upregulating HIF1Α, VEGF, and CD31 expression and reducing ROS levels.
population_specificity: Diabetic wound models (in vivo study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and mechanisms of biological drying technology for water extraction from citric acid dewatered sludge, focusing on ventilation rates.
results_summary: Scheduled intermittent low ventilation rates achieved 41.71% water removal in eight days, with peak temperatures of 60°C maintained for 5.9 days, facilitating lipid degradation and bound water release. The method demonstrated high efficiency in bio-generated heat utilization (82.77% for evaporation) and produced dry sludge suitable for low-cost combustion.
population_specificity: Citric acid fermented sludge and similar industrial waste materials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a chitosan Schiff base modified with citric acid for removing dyes (Bismarck Brown R and Rhodamine B) from wastewater and assess its antibacterial properties.
results_summary: The modified chitosan Schiff base demonstrated high dye removal efficiency, with Langmuir saturation capacities of 348 mg.g-1 for BBR and 145 mg.g-1 for RhB, and exhibited enhanced antibacterial activity against both gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria.
population_specificity: Wastewater treatment (no human or animal subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of a citric acid-loaded hydrogel-coated pancreatic stent for dissolving pancreatic calculi in chronic pancreatitis patients.
results_summary: The stent demonstrated high citric acid loading capacity (0.7 g/g hydrogel), sustained release, and effectively dissolved calculi within 3 days in vitro, with good blood and cell compatibility.
population_specificity: Chronic pancreatitis patients with pancreatic calculi.
effective_dosage: 0.7 g citric acid per gram of hydrogel-coated stent.
study_duration: Not specified (in vitro dissolution observed within 3 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether citric acid could synergize with a phage endolysin to effectively lyse Pseudomonas syringae pv. actinidiae (Psa), a bacterial pathogen affecting kiwifruit.
results_summary: The study found that citric acid destabilized the outer membrane of Psa via acidification and chelation of divalent cations, enabling the endolysin to degrade peptidoglycan and reduce viable Psa below detection levels. Scanning electron microscopy confirmed cell lysis after treatment.
population_specificity: Pseudomonas syringae pv. actinidiae (Psa), a Gram-negative phytopathogen affecting kiwifruit.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of citric acid (CA) and hydrochloric acid (HA) as extraction solvents on the structural properties and biological activities of okra pectic polysaccharides (OPs).
results_summary: CA-OPs exhibited higher esterification degree, solubility, total sugar content, and rhamnogalacturonan-I (RG-I) segments compared to HA-OPs. Ultrasound-assisted superfine grinding extraction with CA improved sugar content, antioxidant capacity, and emulsification ability while reducing molecular weight and viscosity.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on okra pectic polysaccharides)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how citric acid (CA) and phosphate compounds influence the immobilization of cadmium (Cd), lead (Pb), and zinc (Zn) in contaminated soils.
results_summary: Low concentrations of citric acid (2 mmol kg-1 soil) combined with phosphate effectively immobilized Cd, Pb, and Zn, while higher concentrations (>5-20 mmol kg-1 soil) reversed this effect, mobilizing the metals. The P-CA2 treatment was the most effective, primarily through electrostatic adsorption and precipitation mechanisms.
population_specificity: Contaminated rhizospheric soil
effective_dosage: 2 mmol kg-1 soil (low CA), 5-20 mmol kg-1 soil (high CA)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of citric acid in pancreatic cancer pathogenesis and its potential therapeutic effects in mice subjected to a high-fat diet.
results_summary: Citrate treatment significantly promoted tumor cell apoptosis, suppressed cell proliferation, and inhibited tumor growth in vivo by releasing SPARC proteins and repolarizing M2 macrophages into M1 macrophages.
