The study highlights citric acid as a critical metabolite linking obesity and pancreatic cancer.
population_specificity: Mice subjected to a high-fat diet (HFD) as a model for obesity-related pancreatic cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antimicrobial efficacy of citric acid (CA) against Pseudomonas aeruginosa (PA) in burn wound infections using microbiology assays and an ex vivo skin wound model.
results_summary: Citric acid showed significant reductions in bacterial numbers in suspension assays (log10 reduction: 5.77) and was highly effective in reducing PA in biofilms after a 15-minute treatment (log10 reduction ~2.5). However, its efficacy in the skin wound model was not as pronounced as other solutions after longer treatments.
population_specificity: Pseudomonas aeruginosa-infected burn wounds (ex vivo skin wound model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how citric acid (CA) alleviates or tolerates cadmium (Cd) toxicity in Brassica using a proteome approach.
results_summary: The study found that citric acid significantly altered the proteome level in Brassica under Cd toxicity, with 476 proteins showing differential abundance. Key proteins involved in antioxidant defense and sulfur assimilation were identified, suggesting CA's role in Cd-detoxification.
population_specificity: Brassica plants (oilseed crop)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of citric acid as a crosslinking agent in a flame-retardant coating for cotton fabric.
results_summary: Citric acid, as part of the flame-retardant coating, contributed to excellent flame retardant efficiency, with significant reductions in pHRR (58.5%) and THR (73.6%) and a 74% increase in LOI value. The coating maintained high transparency (over 90% transmittance) but slightly reduced mechanical performance.
population_specificity: Cotton fabric treated with flame-retardant coating.
effective_dosage: Not specified for citric acid alone; overall flame-retardant concentration was 5.25 wt%.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether citric acid, in combination with microbial agents, could enhance the remediation of cadmium-contaminated soil by Solanum nigrum L.
results_summary: The study found that citric acid combined with Glomus mosseae and Bacillus megaterium significantly increased cadmium accumulation in plant leaves, improved biomass, and altered rhizosphere microbial communities to enhance cadmium uptake and soil remediation.
population_specificity: Cadmium-contaminated soil and the plant Solanum nigrum L.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the metabolic effects of citric acid on the yeast species *Issatchenkia terricola* WJL-G4, particularly its role in the TCA cycle and other metabolic pathways.
results_summary: The study found that *I. terricola* WJL-G4 metabolized citric acid via the TCA pathway, with glycolysis inhibited but gluconeogenesis unaffected. Citric acid also influenced fatty acids, phospholipids, and amino acid, vitamin, purine, and nicotinamide pathways.
population_specificity: Yeast species *Issatchenkia terricola* WJL-G4 (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether citric acid modification of a collagen film could enhance its antibacterial properties for corneal tissue engineering.
results_summary: Treating collagen films with citric acid significantly increased carboxyl groups on the surface, improving the antibacterial properties of the gentamicin-modified film (ColCA-GM). The modified film demonstrated good physicochemical properties and excellent biocompatibility.
population_specificity: In vitro study (no human or animal subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a computational model integrating metabolic pathways, including the TCA cycle (involving citric acid), to better understand biochemical reaction mechanisms in cells.
results_summary: The study proposed a computational model that achieved high accuracy and stability in observing metabolite concentration changes, though it had limitations in accounting for all reactions. The model could aid in understanding mechanisms related to aging, cancer, and metabolic diseases.
population_specificity: Not specified (computational model based on literature data).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical efficacy and safety of citrate anticoagulation versus heparin anticoagulation in continuous renal replacement therapy for acute kidney injury in sepsis.
results_summary: Citrate anticoagulation showed superior efficacy, including improved renal function, longer filter lifespan, and fewer adverse bleeding reactions compared to heparin anticoagulation. The differences were statistically significant.
population_specificity: Patients with acute kidney injury in sepsis undergoing continuous renal replacement therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether citric acid-modified starch could serve as an effective heavy metal adsorbent, specifically for Cu2+ adsorption.
results_summary: Citric acid treatment (E-CA) resulted in starch with high Cu2+ adsorption capacity (36.23 mg/g), though slightly less effective than the combined phytic and citric acid treatment (E-PACA, 38.13 mg/g). The modification also led to structural changes, loss of crystallinity, and improved water absorption.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on corn starch dispersions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if citric acid (CA) could serve as an effective bone-targeting modifier molecule for estrogen delivery in treating postmenopausal osteoporosis (PMOP).
results_summary: The study found that CA modification significantly increased bone targeting and enabled rapid drug release under acidic bone conditions, reducing bone loss in postmenopausal osteoporotic mice while minimizing estrogenic side effects on the uterus.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal osteoporotic mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether citric acid-activated chlorine dioxide solution could effectively control Ulva prolifera growth and micropropagule release in Neopyropia cultivation rafts.
results_summary: Citric acid-activated chlorine dioxide at ≥250 mg/L effectively killed U. prolifera and its micropropagules, suggesting its utility in preventing green tides. The solution impacted chlorophyll content and fluorescence parameters, indicating physiological damage to the algae.
population_specificity: Ulva prolifera algae in Neopyropia cultivation rafts (marine environment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the combined effect of Bacillus megaterium and citric acid on promoting ryegrass growth and cadmium (Cd) extraction in Cd-contaminated soil.
results_summary: The combined treatment significantly improved oxidative stress defense, photosynthesis, and ryegrass biomass (1.28 times higher than control). It also increased Cd accumulation in shoots (2.31 times higher than control) and enhanced cadmium migration in the rhizosphere.
population_specificity: Ryegrass in cadmium-contaminated soil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of using sugar-sweetened beverages (SSB) for citric acid (CA) production and its impact on reducing chemical oxygen demand (COD) of SSB.
results_summary: The study found that all tested SSB were suitable for CA production, with yields ranging from 13.01 to 56.62 g/L, and COD reduction of 53-75.64%, demonstrating effective SSB waste treatment. The bioprocess offers a low-cost, high-availability alternative to traditional feedstocks for CA production.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study using A. niger and SSB as substrate)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether citric acid (CA) could mitigate chromium stress (Cr-S) tolerance in tomato plants by regulating hydrogen sulfide (H2S) production.
results_summary: CA reduced oxidative stress markers (H2O2, MDA, EL), enhanced plant growth, chlorophyll content, and antioxidant enzyme activity, and increased H2S production in Cr-stressed tomato plants. It also promoted Cr sequestration in root cell walls and leaf vacuoles, reducing toxicity.
population_specificity: Tomato plants (hydroponically grown)
effective_dosage: 100 μM foliar spray daily for 3 days
study_duration: 3 days of CA treatment followed by 10 days of Cr exposure

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a combined treatment system (Ca(OH)2 precipitation and aerobic MBR) for treating high-organic-load citric acid wastewater.
results_summary: The study achieved 97.3% COD removal with Ca(OH)2 precipitation and 92.0% with MBR, resulting in a total COD removal efficiency of 99.8%, reducing COD concentration from 52,000 to 114 mg/L. The combined system proved highly effective for citric acid wastewater treatment.
population_specificity: Wastewater from citric acid production
effective_dosage: Not applicable (treatment parameters: agitation speed 100-200 rpm, temperature 30-70°C, reaction time 2-6 h)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a solution containing 35% 3-O-ethyl-l-ascorbic acid and 50% citric acid (35EA/50CA) could improve the shear bond strength (SBS) of metal brackets on bleached teeth compared to other treatments.
results_summary: The study found that the 35EA/50CA solution significantly improved SBS compared to phosphoric acid treatment (p < 0.001) and restored it to levels comparable to unbleached teeth. The adhesive remnant index (ARI) scores also showed significant differences among the groups.
population_specificity: Forty maxillary premolar teeth (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: 50% citric acid solution applied for 5 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of citric acid treatment, alone and in combination with ultrasound, on the valorisation of hog plum bagasse for potential food applications.
results_summary: Citric acid treatment significantly reduced fiber, hemicellulose, and lignin content while improving cellulose yield, functional properties, and bioactive compounds. It also enhanced antioxidant capacity and reduced microbial contamination to non-detectable levels.
population_specificity: Hog plum bagasse (a fruit waste byproduct).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of citric acid (CA) with other inducers (TG and GDL) on the formation of whey protein isolate-milk fat emulsion gels for embedding lutein and its stability in processed cheese.
results_summary: Citric acid induced faster acidification than GDL, leading to differences in gel structure. CA-induced emulsion gels showed lower physical stability and embedding efficiency for lutein compared to TG, but the processed cheese with CA-induced gels had the highest bioavailability of lutein.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study involving whey protein isolate-milk fat emulsion gels and processed cheese).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the synergistic antimicrobial activity of citric acid combined with palmarosa oil nanoemulsion against Pectobacterium, a pathogen causing soft-rot disease.
results_summary: The combination of citric acid and palmarosa oil nanoemulsion significantly improved storage stability and reduced the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) against Pectobacterium. Citric acid strongly stimulated intracellular ATP depletion, enhancing antimicrobial efficacy.
population_specificity: Pectobacterium, specifically P. carotovorum PCC3.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how citric acid affects the stability, water resistance, and mechanical properties of cellulose nanocrystal (CNC) films.
results_summary: Citric acid acted as a plasticizer without heat treatment, increasing film disintegration in water and water vapor sorption while reducing tensile strength. Combined with heat treatment (≥120°C and ≥20% citric acid), it produced stable, water-resistant films with excellent mechanical properties.
population_specificity: Cellulose nanocrystal films (in vitro study, no human or animal subjects).
study_duration: Not specified (short-term heat treatment of 10 minutes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if human primary ADSCs preconditioned with citric acid-coated magnetic nanoparticles (MNP-CA-PCA) retain their phenotypic features and if their conditioned media elicit immune responses in vitro.
results_summary: MNP-CA-PCA-preconditioned ADSCs showed good viability and retained their mesenchymal stem cell phenotype. Conditioned media from these cells did not increase inflammatory cytokine release or induce proliferation of allergen-stimulated monocytes.
population_specificity: Human primary adipose-derived mesenchymal stem cells (ADSCs) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of citric acid (CA) combined with 5-aminolevulinic acid (ALA) or salicylic acid (SA) on manganese (Mn) absorption and antioxidant defense in sunflower plants.
results_summary: CA increased Mn uptake in sunflower roots but did not improve translocation to shoots. ALA/SA combined with CA activated antioxidant defenses and mitigated Mn toxicity effects.
population_specificity: Six-leaf-old sunflower plants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of estrogen signalling and ERα in cough pathways, specifically examining citric acid-induced cough in guinea pigs.
results_summary: Citric acid-induced cough was significantly augmented in female guinea pigs after ERα degradation or reduced estrogen levels, showing increased cough count and shorter latency, while capsaicin-induced cough remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Female and male guinea pigs

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether incorporating poly(citric acid)-grafted graphene oxide (PGO) into hollow fiber membranes improves antifouling properties and water treatment efficiency.
results_summary: At 0.7 wt% PGO loading, the modified membranes showed higher water permeability, improved bovine serum albumin rejection (97.7%), and significantly enhanced antifouling properties (85% flux recovery rate, 37% better than neat membranes). The improvements were attributed to increased hydrophilicity and structural porosity.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on membrane filtration systems).
effective_dosage: 0.7 wt% PGO in membrane outer layer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of citric acid as a crosslinker in synthesizing CMTG-PVA hydrogel films for wound treatment.
results_summary: Citric acid crosslinked hydrogel films demonstrated good mechanical strength, low protein adsorption, controlled drug release, and effective wound healing in vivo. The films showed optimal performance with higher PVA and lower citric acid concentrations.
population_specificity: In-vivo study (specific population not detailed in abstract).
effective_dosage: Not specified (concentration varied but exact amounts not provided).
study_duration: Not specified (drug release sustained up to 24 hours).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a new amphiphilic polymer (CA-g-AN) using citric acid to improve the hydrophilicity, antifouling property, and permeability of PES ultrafiltration membranes for water treatment.
results_summary: The modified PES membranes with CA-g-AN showed significantly higher water flux (8x improvement) and enhanced hydrophilicity (83.24% flux recovery ratio, 76.43° water contact angle), demonstrating improved antifouling and permeability properties.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on membrane materials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the bacteriostatic effects of citric acid (CA) combined with magnolol (MA) against C. perfringens and its potential to alleviate C. perfringens-induced damage in yellow-hair chickens.
results_summary: The study found that a CA:MA ratio of 50:3 significantly inhibited C. perfringens growth at 265 μg/mL and damaged bacterial cell morphology at 530 μg/mL. In chickens, the CA-MA combination alleviated intestinal damage, inflammation, and oxidative stress by inhibiting TLR/MyD88/NF-κB and Nrf-2/HO-1 signaling pathways.
population_specificity: Yellow-hair chickens challenged with C. perfringens.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether citric acid (CA) could alleviate the inhibitory effects of in-situ produced humic acids (HA) on methane production during anaerobic digestion (AD) of sludge.
results_summary: Citric acid at 0.06–0.10 g/g TS effectively enhanced methane production (up to 2.89 times control levels), but lower dosages (0.02–0.04 g/g TS) initially improved sludge solubilization and hydrolysis before later inhibiting them due to HA rebinding. The effect was dosage-dependent, with higher CA doses deconstructing HA and preventing inhibitory binding.
population_specificity: Sewage sludge undergoing anaerobic digestion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of citric acid (CA) in improving short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) production from waste activated sludge (WAS).
results_summary: The study found that citric acid treatment significantly enhanced SCFAs production, with an optimal yield of 384.4 mg COD/g VSS at 0.08 g CA/g TSS. CA also improved sludge decomposition, substrate biodegradability, and microbial abundance, contributing to higher acetic acid production.
population_specificity: Waste activated sludge (WAS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effects of citric acid modification on starch properties and review its industrial applications.
results_summary: Citric acid treatment modifies starch composition, structure, and function through hydrolysis and esterification, enhancing its industrial applicability by altering properties like digestibility, texture, and film-forming ability. The study highlights the potential for targeted utilization of citric acid-modified starch.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on starch properties, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between plasma citric acid cycle metabolites (including citrate) and cardiovascular disease risk, as well as their interaction with Mediterranean diet interventions.
results_summary: Higher baseline levels of 2-hydroxyglutarate, fumarate, and malate were associated with increased cardiovascular risk, with hazard ratios ranging from 1.33 to 1.47 per standard deviation increment. No interaction was found with dietary interventions.
population_specificity: Participants aged 55-80 years at high cardiovascular risk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of citric acid coating on magnetite nanoparticles for improved dispersion and magnetization in biomedical applications.
results_summary: The study found that citric acid-coated magnetite nanoparticles showed higher saturation magnetization (58 emu/g) and better dispersion compared to uncoated nanoparticles. The coating was confirmed via spectroscopy, and hydraulic discharge treatment enhanced citric acid coverage.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on nanoparticles)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of citric acid in enhancing a pyrite-based photo-Fenton system for degrading pollutants like acetaminophen under sunlight.
results_summary: Citric acid significantly improved the degradation efficiency of acetaminophen (99.1% within 30 min under xenon lamp, 93.9% under natural sunlight) by enhancing H2O2 generation and hydroxyl radical production. A QSAR model confirmed the system's high predictive accuracy for degradation rates.
population_specificity: Pharmaceuticals and personal care products (PPCPs), specifically acetaminophen, in water/wastewater.
study_duration: 30 minutes under xenon lamp, comparable time under natural sunlight.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exogenous citric acid treatment could enhance flavonoid accumulation in *Phellinus igniarius* and optimize the processing conditions for maximum yield.
results_summary: Citric acid significantly increased flavonoid accumulation in *P. igniarius* in a concentration- and time-dependent manner, with optimal results (60.96 mg/g) achieved using 2.77 mM citric acid for 69.74 hours. The study also analyzed changes in flavonoid fingerprint profiles under citric acid treatment.
population_specificity: *Phellinus igniarius* (a medicinal fungus)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether citric acid (CA) could enhance the uptake of heavy metals (Pb, Cr, Ni) in Tagetes erecta L. plants exposed to industrial wastewater and mitigate oxidative stress.
results_summary: Citric acid (5 and 10 mM) improved chlorophyll, protein content, and antioxidant enzyme production while reducing reactive oxygen species (ROS) and electrolyte leakage (EL). It also increased metal accumulation, particularly Pb in roots and Cr/Ni in stems.
population_specificity: Tagetes erecta L. plants grown hydroponically.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of topical 3% citric acid on the healing process of chronic leprosy wounds.
results_summary: The study found improved wound bed appearance, increased granulation tissue, reduced inflammation, decreased bacterial colonies, enhanced type I collagen fibers, and reduced pain and exudation after citric acid treatment.
population_specificity: 5 individuals with chronic leprosy wounds in an outpatient wound care center in Brazil.
effective_dosage: 3% citric acid ointment applied in a thin layer (~2 mm) on alternate days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of citric acid (CA) supplementation in poultry broiler feed with varying levels of calcium (Ca) and total phosphorus (TP) on growth, nutrient utilization, carcass characteristics, and economic outcomes.
results_summary: Birds fed moderately low Ca and TP with 0.5% CA showed higher growth rates, better nutrient utilization, improved dressing percentage, and forequarters weight. The highest economic return was observed with 0.5% CA supplementation in feed containing moderately low Ca and TP.
population_specificity: Commercial broiler poultry birds (Vancobb-400 strain day-old chicks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of citric acid−choline chloride deep eutectic solvent treatment on bamboo pulp fibrillation, esterification, and the resulting properties of cellulose nanofibers (CNFs), including antibacterial activity and their impact on polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) films.
results_summary: The study found that higher temperature and time increased esterification and carboxyl group content in CNFs but reduced yield and diameter. Optimal conditions (120 °C for 24 h) produced CNFs with high antibacterial activity (81.7% inhibition of E. coli, 63.1% of S. aureus) and improved tensile strength (74% enhancement) in PVA composite films, though the films themselves lacked antibacterial properties.
population_specificity: Bamboo pulp-derived cellulose nanofibers (CNFs) and polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) films.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how dual treatment with phytic acid and citric acid modifies the structural and physicochemical properties of normal corn starch.
results_summary: Dual treatment with phytic acid and citric acid induced esterification, altering starch properties such as solubility, transmittance, and resistant starch content. High citric acid concentration (10%) inhibited covalent interaction between phytic acid and starch but increased resistant starch fractions.
population_specificity: Normal corn starch (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of 10% and 40% citric acid on the microhardness of root canal dentin compared to other chelating agents.
results_summary: The study found that both 10% and 40% citric acid significantly decreased dentin microhardness, similar to 17% EDTA and BioAkt, with no statistical differences among the treatments.
population_specificity: Single-root teeth (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the induction mechanism of citric acid in lenthionine synthesis in Shiitake mushrooms and determine optimal treatment conditions.
results_summary: The study found that citric acid treatment at 300 μM for 15 days was effective for lenthionine synthesis, with optimal conditions (406 μM/L, 15.6 days) yielding 130 μg/g lenthionine. Citric acid significantly increased the expression of key enzymes (LEGGT and LECSL) involved in lenthionine biosynthesis.
population_specificity: Shiitake mushrooms (Lentinula edodes)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of a baobab pulp-fortified pearl millet beverage containing citric acid in improving iron and anemia status among adolescent girls in Ghana.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding citric acid's effects, but the study design suggests it was included as part of a fortified beverage to enhance iron absorption. The primary outcomes measured were serum ferritin and hemoglobin concentrations.
population_specificity: Anaemic adolescent girls (258 participants) in the Kumbungu District of Ghana.
effective_dosage: 222.1 mg citric acid per 350 ml beverage, administered once a day, five times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential role of alpha-ketoglutarate (AKG) in aging and age-related diseases, including its metabolic and cellular regulatory functions.
results_summary: The abstract suggests AKG has pleiotropic functions, including antioxidant effects, metabolic regulation, and potential benefits in muscle growth, wound healing, and post-surgery recovery, but lacks recent human studies confirming its role in aging or age-related diseases.
population_specificity: Studies referenced include worms, mice, and limited human studies from the 1980s and 1990s.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current knowledge on the role of citrate in bone metabolism and its implications for bone disorder pathophysiology and medical management.
results_summary: The study highlights that citrate is a key component in bone metabolism, with 90% of the body's citrate residing in mineralized tissues, and reviews progress in understanding its role in bone disorders.
population_specificity: General human population, with focus on bone metabolism.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential of triheptanoin, a triglyceride of heptanoate, as an alternative energy source in conditions where citric acid cycle intermediates or fatty acid degradation are impaired.
results_summary: The study found that triheptanoin supplementation has been used to treat neurological diseases with disturbed glucose metabolism and metabolic disorders involving impaired β-oxidation, showing benefits in epilepsy due to GLUT1 deficiency and long-chain fatty acid oxidation disorders.
population_specificity: Patients with neurological diseases (e.g., GLUT1 deficiency) and metabolic disorders (e.g., long-chain fatty acid oxidation disorders).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature on the effects of polydextrose (PDX) supplementation on health, including its prebiotic potential and physiological benefits.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that PDX, which contains citric acid, has prebiotic potential and provides physiological benefits similar to other dietary fibers, but it does not specifically detail citric acid's effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (general dietary intervention context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze how mitochondrial genome influences embryo development, cellular differentiation, and offspring health, with a focus on the role of factors associated with the citric acid cycle in modulating DNA methylation patterns.
results_summary: The study found that mitochondrial DNA influences chromosomal gene expression in embryos by modulating DNA methylation through citric acid cycle-associated factors, which can affect the TET pathway and the cell's methylation state. It also highlighted the importance of maintaining a single population of mitochondrial DNA for offspring health.
population_specificity: Mammalian species, with specific reference to livestock production.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of citric acid cycle intermediates, particularly pyruvate, in cancer cell proliferation and mitochondrial function, and to assess the impact of MCT inhibition on these processes.
results_summary: The study found that pyruvate supplementation increased mitochondrial oxygen consumption and respiratory capacity, correlating with enhanced cancer cell proliferation. Inhibition of pyruvate uptake via MCT blockade impaired mitochondrial respiration and reduced cell growth.
population_specificity: Breast cancer cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic effects of triheptanoin (C7) versus trioctanoin (C8) in patients with long-chain fatty acid oxidation disorders (LC-FAODs), focusing on energy expenditure, cardiac function, and exercise tolerance.
results_summary: C7 improved left ventricular ejection fraction by 7.4% and reduced left ventricular wall mass by 20%, while also lowering heart rate during exercise compared to C8. No significant differences were found in total energy expenditure, phosphocreatine recovery, body composition, or secondary outcomes between the groups.
population_specificity: 32 patients with LC-FAODs (carnitine palmitoyltransferase-2, very long-chain acylCoA dehydrogenase, trifunctional protein, or long-chain 3-hydroxy acylCoA dehydrogenase deficiencies).
effective_dosage: 20% of total daily energy intake from either C7 or C8.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of a microencapsulated mixture of citric acid and sorbic acid (OA) combined with pure botanicals (PB) on intestinal integrity and functionality in weaned pigs and in vitro on Caco-2 cells.
results_summary: The study found that OA + PB improved intestinal maturation by reducing inflammatory markers (IL-12, TGF-β, IL-6) and enhancing trans-epithelial electrical resistance (TER) in Caco-2 cells, suggesting a less permeable intestine. While dextran flux was not significantly affected, a trend toward reduced permeability was observed.
population_specificity: Weaned piglets and Caco-2 cell monolayers.
effective_dosage: 5 g/kg in pig diets; 0.2 g/l and 1 g/l in Caco-2 cells.
study_duration: 2 weeks for piglets; up to 14 days for Caco-2 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether empagliflozin therapy affected citrulline levels in patients with HFpEF and explore potential links to cardiovascular protection.
results_summary: Empagliflozin significantly increased citrulline levels in HFpEF patients (3.57±1.88 vs. 6.47±3.78; P=0.006), suggesting a possible metabolic pathway for its cardiovascular benefits, though further studies are needed.
population_specificity: 16 patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of dietary L-Citrulline supplementation on milk production and composition in Alpine dairy goats.
results_summary: CIT-treated goats showed increased daily milk production, solid-non-fat content, and protein content in milk compared to the control group. The study also noted significant effects of lactation day and sire on milk production.
population_specificity: Alpine dairy goats
study_duration: 40 days (from parturition to day 40 of lactation)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate citrulline's role in aging by examining its effects on cellular senescence, DNA damage, inflammation, and metabolic regulation in aging mice.
results_summary: Citrulline was found to be consistently down-regulated in aging mice and demonstrated anti-aging effects by reducing cellular senescence, protecting against DNA damage, modulating macrophage metabolism, and mitigating inflammation. Long-term supplementation improved age-associated phenotypes and suppressed proinflammatory responses via mTOR pathway inhibition.
population_specificity: Aged mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of dietary L-citrulline supplementation on production performance, antioxidant and immune properties, and intestinal microbiota in broilers.
results_summary: L-citrulline supplementation significantly improved body weight, average daily weight gain, antioxidant capacity, immune function, and modulated intestinal microbiota, with optimal effects observed at 1-1.5% dietary inclusion.
population_specificity: 1-day-old male yellow-feathered broilers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the radioprotective properties of L-citrulline and its molecular mechanism in mitigating intestinal and hematological damage caused by internal radiation exposure.
results_summary: L-citrulline demonstrated radioprotective effects in vitro and in vivo, facilitated histone H3 citrullination (H3Cit17), and regulated transcription of protective genes like Cxcl3, which shielded intestinal epithelial cells from radiation damage.
population_specificity: Mice exposed to yttrium-90 (Y90) carbon microspheres.
effective_dosage: Not specified for L-citrulline (Y90 dosages ranged from 0-5.0 mCi).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify whether citrulline could inhibit C. difficile-mediated colitis and prevent recurrence by exerting anti-inflammatory effects.
results_summary: Citrulline preserved mucosal integrity, reduced inflammatory markers (MIP-1a), increased anti-inflammatory IL-10 expression, and synergized with vancomycin to prevent recurrence in animal models. It also ameliorated colitis in multiple infection scenarios.
population_specificity: Human colonic tissues, primary human cells, humanized mice (HuCD34-NCG), hamsters, and C57BL/6J mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the presence and clinical utility of the cyclic derivative of citrulline in urine as a marker for citrullinemia type I and correlate it with plasma citrulline levels.
results_summary: The study found a positive correlation between the concentration of the cyclic derivative of citrulline in urine and plasma citrulline levels, establishing it as a good marker for citrullinemia type I, though not unique to this condition. The mass spectrum matched the chemical structure proposed by Wilson et al. in 1978.
population_specificity: Patients with conditions associated with elevated plasma citrulline levels, including citrullinemia type I.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential role of L-citrulline supplementation in treating neonatal conditions like necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) and bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD)-associated pulmonary hypertension (PH).
results_summary: L-citrulline supplementation mitigated pulmonary vascular structural changes, preserved alveolar growth, and increased vascular endothelial growth factor gene expression in animal models. Pharmacokinetic studies in neonates indicated doses of 100-300 mg/kg/day were safe and well-tolerated, but efficacy evidence in human neonates remains limited.
population_specificity: Preterm infants and neonatal animal models (rodents and piglets) with conditions like NEC, BPD-PH, and chronic hypoxia-induced PH.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if oral L-citrulline supplementation could prolong pregnancy duration and improve outcomes in females with preeclampsia.
results_summary: The study found no benefit of L-citrulline in prolonging pregnancy, improving fetal growth, or enhancing maternal/neonatal outcomes. Systolic blood pressure and liver enzyme levels were higher in the treated group at delivery.
population_specificity: 115 females with monofetal preeclamptic pregnancy before 36 weeks of gestation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore citrulline's emerging therapeutic applications beyond urea cycle disorders, focusing on conditions associated with nitric oxide deficiency, endothelial dysfunction, and oxidative stress.
results_summary: Citrulline shows promise in improving outcomes for sickle cell disease, post-operative pulmonary hypertension, hepatic veno-occlusive disease, and bronchopulmonary dysplasia by enhancing nitric oxide production and reducing oxidative stress. However, further research is needed to confirm optimal dosing and long-term efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients with sickle cell disease, post-operative pulmonary hypertension, hepatic veno-occlusive disease, bronchopulmonary dysplasia, and speculative applications in asthma and acute respiratory distress syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether L-citrulline, mediated by Lactobacillus murinus, could alleviate insulin resistance by promoting fatty acid oxidation and inhibiting gluconeogenesis.
results_summary: L-citrulline significantly increased in concentration after L. murinus administration and improved insulin resistance by reducing body weight gain, postprandial blood glucose, and inflammation while promoting fatty acid oxidation and inhibiting gluconeogenesis.
population_specificity: Insulin resistance animal models

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether L-citrulline could protect against palmitic acid-induced cell death in bovine mammary epithelial cells by inhibiting endoplasmic reticulum and oxidative stress.
results_summary: L-citrulline pretreatment effectively rescued cell viability, reduced reactive oxygen species levels, and downregulated stress-related gene and protein expressions induced by palmitic acid.
population_specificity: Bovine mammary epithelial cells (MAC-T cells)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the therapeutic efficacy of ADI-PEG20, which elevates l-citrulline, in mitigating diabetic complications such as retinopathy, neuropathy, and impaired wound healing in a type 2 diabetes mouse model.
results_summary: ADI-PEG20 treatment reduced oxidative stress and inflammation, improved blood-retinal barrier function, visual acuity, thermal sensitivity, and wound healing in diabetic mice. The anti-inflammatory effects were linked to l-arginine depletion and l-citrulline elevation, blocking the JAK2-STAT1 pathway.
population_specificity: db/db mice (a model of type 2 diabetes)
effective_dosage: Not specified (intraperitoneal, intramuscular, or intravitreal injections of ADI-PEG20 or PEG20 control)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the correlation between oxidative stress, blood amino acids (including citrulline), and nitric oxide metabolism in COVID-19 pneumonia patients.
results_summary: Patients with severe COVID-19 pneumonia showed reduced serum citrulline levels, which correlated negatively with oxidative stress markers. Citrulline levels increased during recovery, suggesting a potential role in disease progression.
population_specificity: 100 adult patients hospitalized for COVID-19 pneumonia between July 2020 and August 2021.
study_duration: Not specified (study compared admission and recovery periods)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether ADI-PEG20 with or without supplemental citrulline could mitigate hypovolemic shock, maintain tissue arginine levels, and reduce systemic inflammation in an endotoxemic pediatric pig model.
results_summary: ADI-PEG20 and citrulline supplementation did not improve hypotension but reduced systemic and local inflammation in the lung and liver. Plasma arginine levels remained low in treated pigs, but tissue arginine levels were similar across groups.
population_specificity: 3-week-old crossbred piglets (pediatric model).
study_duration: 5-hour LPS infusion protocol following a 24-hour pre-treatment period.
